Project Description  The Nurek 500 kV Switchyard Reconstruction Project (the Project) 
will build a new Nurek 500 kV switchyard on a new site within the 
Nurek Hydroelectric Power Plant (HEPP) complex to replace the 
existing Nurek 500 kilovolt (kV) switchyard. The existing 500 kV 
equipment will be dismantled and will mostly be used as spare 
parts for other 500 kV substations.  
   
Rationale  Nurek  HEPP,  incorporating  220  kV  and  500  kV  switchyards, 
produces  over  70%  of  Tajikistan's  electricity  and  performs  a 
frequency  regulation  role  for  the  Central  Asian  power  system, 
which  includes  the  electricity  systems  of  Kazakhstan,  Kyrgyz 
Republic, Turkmenistan, and Uzbekistan.  
 
The existing switchyards were built more than 30 years ago with 
Soviet technology and replacement parts are no longer available. 
They are therefore in need of complete replacement.   
 
Severe  subsidence  in  areas  of  the  switchyards  has  been 
occurring  for  many  years,  requiring  major  ongoing  remedial 
measures. This is due to an extensive salt dome in the vicinity of 
the  switchyards  that  destabilizes  the  ground  conditions  during 
snow melt and rain. There are risks for both switchyards that a 
catastrophic  event  may  occur  at  any  time,  thereby  destroying 
major parts of the switchgear. Ground stabilization measures are 
considered impractical.   
 
The  Government  of  Tajikistan  (the  Government)  considers  the 
reconstruction of the switchyards to be emergency projects due to 
the  deteriorating  equipment  and  unstable  geological  site 
conditions that could result in the potential loss of major output 
from the Nurek HEPP for lengthy periods. 
 
A 2006 feasibility study recommended that the equipment in both 
switchyards be retired, with new switchyards to be built on secure 
ground. The study recommended that the least-cost option was to

ii     
 
 
  utilize a portion of the land where the existing 220 kV switchyard 
is  currently  located  for  both  new  switchyards.  The  ground 
conditions  of  the  proposed  new  site  have  been  verified  as 
satisfactory by geological investigation. 
 
Gas-insulated switchgear technology, which uses approximately 
10% of the area required by conventional air-insulated switchgear 
technology, is required due to the restricted area of the proposed 
new site. 
 
The  Government  signed  a  loan  agreement  with  the  German 
Development Cooperation through Kreditanstalt für Wiederaufbau 
(Credit  Institute  for  Reconstruction)  in  August  2008  for  the 
financing of the new 220 kV gas-insulated switchgear switchyard, 
with a projected completion date of April 2011. The Project under 
Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  financing  will  complete  the 
required rehabilitation of the switchyards. 
   
Impact and Outcome  The impact is sustainable and reliable electricity supply to support 
economic development. It will mitigate the risk of natural disasters 
disabling the switchyard, and will stabilize the flow of electricity 
coming from the strategically important Nurek HEPP.  
 
The outcome is the reliable evacuation of Nurek HEPP electricity 
to the grid.

Allocation and Relending  Allocation 
Terms  A grant of $54.77 million will be provided from ADB’s Special 
Funds resources to the Government.   
 
Relending 
The Government will lend the proceeds of the grant to Barki Tajik 
under a subsidiary loan agreement which will require Barki Tajik to 
repay the loan to the Government at an interest rate of 5% per 
annum over a tenor of 25 years, including a 5-year grace period. 
 
Use of Subsidiary Loan Repayments 
The  Government  shall  ensure  that  receipt  of  repayments  of 
principal and interest by Barki Tajik arising from the subsidiary 
loan  agreement  will  be  used  exclusively  for  Government  tariff 
subsidies for poor and vulnerable electricity consumers.   
   
Estimated Project  The Project will be implemented over a 5-year period commencing 
Completion Date  in February 2009. The duration of the turnkey contract will be 
approximately  3  years,  including  the  1-year  guarantee  period 
between  the  taking  over  and  the  completion  of  the  warranty 
period. The estimated project completion date is 31 January 2014. 
The period of utilization is until 31 July 2014. 
   
Executing Agency  Barki Tajik Joint Stock Holding Company, the 100% state-owned 
and  vertically  integrated  power  utility  company  and  owner  of 
Nurek HEPP. 
   
Implementation  The  Government  has  created  a  state  agency  to  act  as  an 
Arrangements  independent  project  management  unit  to  coordinate  and 
implement  power  projects  that  are  funded  through  loans  and 
grants  from  bilateral  donors  and  international  financing 
institutions. Barki Tajik shall employ the services of the project 
management unit for day-to-day management of the Project and 
shall  be  the  party  to  sign  all  contracts  with  consultants  and 
contractors employed on the Project.  
   
Procurement  One turnkey contract for the entire Project will be procured by 
Barki Tajik using international competitive bidding in accordance 
with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2007, as amended from time 
to time). 
   
Consulting Services  A total of 85 person-months of consulting services, comprising 
mostly international consultants, will be required for the Project. 
One  consulting  firm  will  be  recruited  as  the  implementation 
consultant,  to  be  selected  and  engaged  by  Barki  Tajik  in 
accordance  with  ADB’s  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of  Consultants 
(2007, as amended from time to time). Quality- and cost-based 
selection method with weighting of 90:10 will be adopted, since 
the consequences of poor performance could be high, leading to 
catastrophic economic, financial, and social losses.

iv     
 
 
Project Benefits and  The  primary  beneficiaries  of  the  Project  will  be  business 
Beneficiaries  enterprises  and  the  population  who  will  benefit  from  a  stable 
supply  of  electricity  services  and  long-term  cost  reductions 
resulting  from  economic  dispatch  of  electricity  from  the  Nurek 
HEPP  and  the  overall  efficiencies  gained  from  enhanced 
transmission through the new switchyards. The financial internal 
rate of return of the Project is estimated at 9.3% and the economic 
internal rate of return is estimated at 36.7%.  
   
Risks and Assumptions  The  Project  is  technically  complicated  given  its  advanced 
technology content and the need for the two new switchyards to 
be integrated both with each other and with the existing power 
station. However, the overall technical risk is deemed to be low.   
 
Rehabilitation of the nine turbine and generators of Nurek HEPP 
is not included in the Project but will need to be carried out in the 
medium term. It is assumed that total failure of Nurek HEPP will 
not occur as the nine units operate independently of each other 
and any one unit can be repaired and rehabilitated at the time of 
failure, as has been recent practice.    
 
At  a  policy  level,  it  is  assumed  that  the  Government  (i)  will 
implement full cost-recovery tariffs, and (ii) is committed to making 
available the necessary investments to rehabilitate and develop 
the electricity sector. 
 
At  an  institutional  level,  it  is  assumed  that  Barki  Tajik  will  (i) 
implement  needed  reforms  with  the  modernization  of  its 
management,  governance,  and  corporate  procedures;  and  (ii) 
deliver  on  its  assurances  to  improve  collection  levels  and 
adequately fund operation and maintenance.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed grant 
to the Republic of Tajikistan for the Nurek 500 kV Switchyard Reconstruction Project (the 
Project). The design and monitoring framework of the Project is in Appendix 1.   
 
II.  RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 
A.  Performance Indicators and Analysis 
2.  Tajikistan possesses vast amounts of hydroelectric (40 gigawatts [GW]) and coal (3,600 
million tons) energy resources, of which only a small fraction (less than 10% of the hydroelectric 
and negligible coal) has been developed. The power sector alone represents up to 5% of gross 
domestic product and is a critical input for the main exports of cotton and aluminum. Meanwhile, 
the country faces energy deficits and cannot meet its winter demand, with the deficits in the 
winter of 2007/2008 being particularly severe. 
3.  Tajikistan has an installed generation capacity of 4,326 megawatts (MW), of which 98% 
is hydroelectric power-based. The predominance of hydroelectric energy creates a problem as 
hydropower production exceeds demand in summer and is reduced in winter when glacial melt 
is least and demand is most. As a result, Tajikistan imports electricity and fossil fuels in winter to 
meet energy needs, and has excess water during summer.   
4.  Per capita domestic energy consumption, at about 0.5 ton of oil equivalent, is very high 
given  the  country's  level  of  economic  development.  This  is  because  of  the  low  end-use 
efficiency and high heating requirements during winter. With the rise in prices of imported fuel, 
households have switched from organic fuels to electricity for heating and cooking, reflecting the 
fact that electricity is the only form of reliable energy available and the Government’s below-cost 
pricing policies have encouraged a shift to electricity away from other forms of energy. 
5.  Until recently, average electricity tariffs were considerably below cost-recovery levels, 
with the average tariff in 2006 of $0.006 per kilowatt-hour (kWh). Since 2007, Tajikistan has 
implemented three tariff increases and is on schedule to bring the average tariff to a financially 
viable level of $0.025/kWh (in 2008 terms) by 2010. In the gas sector, the current tariffs have 
been increased so that they are closer to the financial viability levels. Coal prices are market 
based. 
6.  Electricity consumption in 2005 was 15 million gigawatt-hours (GWh), with the main user 
groups being industry (51%), agriculture (15%), and households (28.2%), and with Tajikistan 
Aluminum Company (TALCO) accounting for approximately 44.3% of total industrial use. The 
high percentage usage by industry and agriculture reflects the subsidized nature of the tariffs to 
these groups.   
 
7.  Investments in the power sector since the break-up of the former Soviet Union have 
been limited to emergency rehabilitation measures, a new 500 kilovolt (kV) transmission line, a 
metering  project,  and  completion  of  the  Sangtuda  I  Hydroelectric  Power  Plant  (HEPP). 
Meanwhile, physical infrastructure continues to deteriorate, leading to high network losses and 
reduced reliability. In addition, commercial losses are high, partly due to the legacy of supplying 
energy without meters and partly due to the lack of commercial orientation within the utilities.  
8.  Barki Tajik Joint Stock Holding Company, a joint stock company 100% owned by the 
state, is a vertically integrated utility, consisting of a network of 10 subsidiary power generation

2   
 
companies, 17 subsidiary distribution companies, and 4 supporting companies (such enterprise 
as Energosnab and Repair-Mechanical Plant). It serves a customer base of approximately 1 
million people and employed 11,200 staff in 2007.  
 
9.  Tajikistan has not appointed an independent energy regulator. Instead, the Ministry of 
Economic Development and Trade regulates the prices of electricity, natural gas, and district 
heat,  while  the  Fuel  and  Energy  Department  in  the  Office  of  the  President  has  overall 
responsibility for the energy sector. This arrangement is not in line with industry best practice, 
with the Government holding both tariff setting and ownership functions. A sector and subsector 
analysis is in Appendix 2.   
 
B.  Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 
1.  Key Power Sector Issues  
10.  Winter supply deficit continues to be a problem, despite import of electricity from the 
Kyrgyz Republic, Turkmenistan, and Uzbekistan. Barki Tajik is implementing improved rationing 
procedures  whereby  load  shedding  commences  earlier  in  the  season,  with  the  result  of 
improved  supply  during  the  coldest  winter  months.  However,  solution  of  the  winter  deficit 
problem will require new HEPPs with seasonal water storage capacity and/or additional thermal 
generation capacity.   
 
11.  Electricity infrastructure is in poor technical condition. The infrastructure needs to be 
expanded to cater for increased demand and outdated equipment needs to be replaced. The 
Project will address part of this need with the reconstruction of one of the most outdated and 
critical components of the system. 
 
12.  The Ministry of Economic Development and Trade, and Barki Tajik, have agreed on an 
approach to tariff rationalization and increase. Tariff categories have been reduced to six (albeit 
with further subgroups) and favorable tariffs for low-usage customers and special summer and 
winter tariffs for TALCO have been eliminated. The weighed average tariff is forecast to be 
$0.025/kWh (in 2008 terms) in 2010, a three times increase of the average tariff from 2006. 
Following the most recent increase in July 2008, the weighted average tariff is $0.0017/kWh. 
Nevertheless, further tariff rationalization and increases are required in order to eliminate cross 
subsidies and fully cover Barki Tajik costs.   
 
13.  The Ministry of Energy and Industry is responsible for coordinating the Government's 
energy  policy.  The  Ministry  of  Economic  Development  and  Trade  regulates  the  prices  of 
electricity, natural gas, and district heat. The Ministry of Environmental Protection is responsible 
for environmental regulation of energy operations. The Committee on State Property exercises 
ownership functions over state-owned assets. The practice of the Government holding both tariff 
setting and ownership functions is not in line with industry best practice. This institutional 
framework does not reflect the needs of a market-oriented economy. 
 
14.  The state-owned Barki Tajik is in need of major restructuring. Its organizational structure 
does not reflect modern utility practice, while the company itself is in poor financial condition 
following years of below-cost tariffs, high losses, and poor collection rates. Barki Tajik needs to 
be reorganized to reflect the commercial nature of its business.

3 
 
15.  Despite  having  abundant  electricity  generation  potential,  including  some  partly 
completed  hydropower  resources  and  power  deficit  markets  in  neighboring  countries,  the 
country is not optimally exploiting its export potential. 
 
2.  Government Strategy 
16.  In 2005, the Government developed a strategy based on a two-track approach for the 
domestic and export markets, as follows:  
 
(i)  The first track focuses on meeting the demand of the domestic market, and 
comprises a set of policy and investment measures aimed to bring the sector to 
reasonable operating conditions and improve its financial viability. The policy 
measures include (a) the implementation of a medium-term tariff policy; (b) a 
social protection policy for energy services to improve the effectiveness of the 
scheme and ensure a more targeted approach to support the poor; and (c) an 
institutional reform policy for the energy sector to improve the transparency and 
efficiency of operations, enable electricity trade, and pave the way for private 
sector  participation  in  the  sector.  The  investment  measures  include 
implementation of programs for (a) increased energy efficiency; (b) demand-side 
management, including a heat supply strategy; and (c) increasing energy supply 
to meet winter demand, with focus on rehabilitation of existing assets.  
 
(ii)  The second track focuses on increasing electricity exports by (a) using existing 
seasonal surpluses in the summer, and (b) attracting private sector investors to 
join  in  developing  newer  hydroelectric  and  thermal  capacities  for  exports  to 
neighboring and regional countries.   
 
3.  Asian Development Bank Strategy 
17.  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) strategy for the energy sector in Tajikistan is to 
ensure that domestic energy demands are met from a sustainable and viable industry and to 
assist in the development of country’s considerable hydropower export potential. This strategy is 
to  be  achieved  through  (i)  improvements  in  the  sector’s  institutional  structure,  operational 
efficiency, and financial performance; and (ii) support in the development of regional energy 
trade  projects.  This  is  consistent  with  ADB’s  Long-term  Strategic  Framework  2008–2020 
(Strategy 2020)1 where support of infrastructure development and regional cooperation are core 
areas.  The Project is not included in the current country partnership strategy for Tajikistan but 
has been added in ADB’s 2008 country assistance program following the Government’s request 
on 16 July 2008. 
 
4.  Project Rationale 
18.  Nurek HEPP produces over 70% of Tajikistan's electricity and performs a frequency 
regulation role for the Central Asian power system.2 Reliable operation of Nurek HEPP is critical 
to meet Tajikistan electric supply requirements and is an important aspect of Central Asian 
Power System operation.

19.  The existing switchyards use obsolete Soviet technology for which replacement parts 
are no longer available. The equipment in both switchyards has exceeded its useful life and is in 
need of complete replacement. In the absence of equipment replacement, the availability of 
both switchyards will deteriorate in the coming years, thereby curtailing Nurek HEPP output.   
 
20.  Nurek HEPP, situated 75 kilometers east of Dushanbe, the capital of Tajikistan, was 
commissioned in 1972 and produces 11,200 GWh within an average hydrological year. Nurek 
has nine generator and turbine units with total installed capacity of 3,000 MW. Six generator and 
turbine units are connected to the Nurek 500 kV switchyard and three to the Nurek 220 kV 
switchyard. Both switchyards currently use air-insulated switchgear (AIS) and are in separate 
locations within the Nurek HEPP complex.  
 
21.  Severe subsidence in areas of the 500 kV and 220 kV switchyards has been occurring 
for many years, requiring major ongoing remedial measures. This is due to an extensive salt 
dome in the vicinity of the switchyards that destabilizes the ground conditions during times of 
snow melt and rain. There are risks for both switchyards that a catastrophic event may occur at 
any time, thereby destroying major parts of the switchgear. Ground stabilization measures are 
considered impractical. There are also regular landslides in the immediate vicinity of the 500 kV 
site, making the location yet more unattractive for an electrical installation.   
 
22.  The Government considers the reconstruction of the 220 kV and 500 kV switchyards to 
be emergency projects due to the deteriorating equipment, unstable geological site conditions, 
and the potential for loss of major portions of Nurek HEPP output for lengthy periods. 
 
23.  A  2006  feasibility  study  conducted  by  consulting  engineers  Fichtner  of  Germany 
recommended that the equipment in both switchyards be retired with new switchyards to be built 
on secure ground. The study examined various alternative sites for the new switchyards. Such 
alternatives were limited due to the mountainous location and the salt dome footprint. The study 
concluded that the least-cost option was to utilize a portion of the existing 220 kV switchyard for 
both new switchyards, with the ground conditions of the proposed new site having been verified 
as satisfactory by geological investigation. Gas-insulated switchgear (GIS) technology, which 
uses  approximately  10%  of  the  area  required  by  AIS  technology,  is  required  due  to  the 
restricted area of the proposed new site. 
 
24.  The Government signed a loan agreement with the German Development Cooperation 
through Kreditanstalt für Wiederaufbau (Credit Institute for Reconstruction) in August 2008 for 
the financing of the new 220 kV GIS switchyard with a projected completion date of April 2011. 
The Project under ADB financing will complete the required rehabilitation of the switchyards. 
 
5.  External Assistance 
25.  The first track of the Government’s strategy—to focus on the domestic market—is being 
supported by the multilateral and bilateral donor community through a range of rehabilitation 
projects (Appendix 3). The proposed Nurek 500 kV Switchyard Reconstruction Project, which 
will enable continued electricity supply to Tajikistan, is consistent with this strategy. On 16 July 
2008, the Government requested ADB’s financial assistance to implement the Project.

5 
 
26.  ADB-funded technical assistance (TA) 3 is assisting the Ministry of Energy and Industry 
in preparing options for the restructuring of Barki Tajik, and in implementing the options, with TA 
completion due in 2010. A United States Trade and Development Agency-funded study, due to 
commence at the end of 2008, will examine the viability of commercial coal mine developments, 
for which a thermal power plant would be a potential customer. Sangtuda1 HEPP (670 MW 
capacity),  70%  owned  by  RAO  UES  of  Russia  and  30%  by  the  Government,  is  under 
construction, with full capacity operation scheduled for 2009.   
27.  Following the Shanghai Cooperation Organization Meeting in Tajikistan in August 2008, 
the  governments  of  the  People’s  Republic  of  China  and  the  Russian  Federation  signed 
agreements with the Government of Tajikistan to finance four new HEPPs, three of which will be 
financed by the Russian Federation (the largest with a capacity of 250 MW) and one by the 
People’s Republic of China (with a 200 MW capacity).   
28.  Tajikistan continues to promote the development of Rogun HEPP (3,600 MW capacity), 
construction of which started during the Soviet era but has since been suspended. A World 
Bank-funded feasibility study is due to commence in late 2008. This major project would serve 
the dual purposes of meeting Tajikistan's winter demand and allowing Tajikistan to export the 
considerable surplus energy.   
29.  The second track of the Government’s strategy—to focus on the export market—is being 
implemented with (i) the signing of ADB loans4 for construction of the Afghanistan–Tajikistan 
transmission interconnection, and (ii) the ongoing development of the Central Asia–South Asia 
regional electricity market5 (CASAREM) project, which envisages the building of a high voltage 
transmission interconnection to allow electricity exports from the Kyrgyz Republic and Tajikistan 
to Afghanistan and Pakistan, both of which are energy deficient.   
6.  Lessons 
30.  Delays were experienced in the implementation of early ADB projects due to project staff 
being  unfamiliar  with  ADB  procurement  procedures  and  inexperienced  with  international 
projects.  However,  the  proposed  project  management  unit  (PMU)  has  learned  from  its 
experiences and its implementation of ongoing ADB-assisted projects is satisfactory.   
 
31.  Previous loan covenants requiring the introducing of cost-recovery tariffs have not been 
fully implemented due to resistance from poor and vulnerable customers who have difficulty in 
paying  the  existing  low  tariffs.  The  project  design  addresses  this  issue  by  requiring  the 
Government to use the subsidiary loan repayments to subsidize targeted customers while 
ensuring that Barki Tajik raises its tariff to a full cost-recovery level.   
 
32.  Barki Tajik is weak in nontechnical areas of governance, human resource management, 
financial controls, and commercial awareness. Reform is proving to be a slow process, with the 
Government and Barki Tajik being generally resistant to change. However, the Government has 
now indicated its intention to proceed with the delayed restructuring of Barki Tajik.

III.  THE PROPOSED PROJECT 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
34.  The  impact  of  the  Project  is  sustainable  and  reliable  electricity  supply  to  support 
economic development. It will mitigate the risk of natural disasters disabling the switchyard, and 
will stabilize the flow of electricity coming from the strategically important Nurek HEPP. The 
outcome of the Project is the reliable evacuation of Nurek HEPP electricity to the grid.  
  
B.  Outputs 
35.  The Project output is the building of a new Nurek 500 kV switchyard on a new site within 
the Nurek Hydroelectric Power Plant (HEPP) complex, which will replace the existing Nurek 500 
kilovolt (kV) switchyard. The existing 500 kV equipment will be dismantled and will mostly be 
used as spare parts for other 500 kV substations. Old metals will be sold to local recycling 
companies. The new Nurek 500 kV switchyard will utilize GIS technology, which only requires 
approximately 10% of the area required by AIS technology used in the existing switchyards.  
 
C.  Special Features 
36.  Current  Barki  Tajik  tariff  methodology  employs  rates  that  are  below  the  long-run 
marginal cost and incorporates cross subsidies between different consumer categories. This is 
inconsistent with international best utility practice whereby tariffs should cover costs without 
cross subsidies. In the event that the Government identifies a particular consumer class that 
requires a subsidy, this should be funded directly by the Government in a transparent manner.  
 
37.  In accordance with the Government’s strategy, Barki Tajik’s tariffs are to be increased 
such that Barki Tajik’s future income will be sufficient to cover costs, repay debt, and provide 
adequate return on equity investments. As Barki Tajik will perform as a commercial company, it 
should therefore not in itself be the recipient of the ADB grant.  
 
38.  ADB will provide the project funds to the Government through a grant agreement. The 
Government will then lend the Government’s share and ADB’s share of the Project funds to 
Barki Tajik through a subsidiary loan agreement acceptable to ADB. Barki Tajik repayments to 
the Government of the principal and interest arising from this subsidiary loan agreement will be 
used exclusively to subsidize the poor and vulnerable electricity consumers in accordance with 
a methodology agreed with ADB and reflected in such subsidiary loan agreement.

1.  Corporate Overview 
55.  Barki Tajik, the Executing Agency, is the state-owned utility responsible for generation, 
transmission, and distribution of electricity in Tajikistan. Prior to the country’s independence, it 
was administratively a Government entity. In 1992, Barki Tajik became a state joint stock 
holding company. Although it is fully owned by the Government, Barki Tajik enjoys autonomous

a formal separation of operations has taken place along its business lines. In 2004, Barki Tajik 
was merged with the Ministry of Energy and Industry. In March 2006, this merger was revoked 
and Barki Tajik separated from the Ministry of Energy and Industry.

Government. Ten general services departments (among them planning, accounting, and sales) 
report directly to the Barki Tajik chair, who also manages issues of great importance, such as 
the  power  supply  contract  with  TALCO  (the  largest  industrial  consumer  with  40%  of  total 
consumption), or the financing of new investment projects. The overall staff of the utility totals 
11,480 people, of which about 290 work in the head office in Dushanbe.

IV.  PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, ASSUMPTIONS, AND RISKS 
A.  Financial and Economic Benefits  
63.  Financial Benefits. Financial analysis of the Project was carried out in accordance with 
ADB guidelines.8 All financial costs and benefits were expressed at constant 2008 prices. Cost 
streams used to determine the financial internal rate of return—i.e. capital investment, operation 
and maintenance, insurance costs, and taxes—reflect the costs of delivering the estimated 
benefits. The wheeling charges were computed from the current approved tariffs and have been 
used on an annually fixed basis to estimate the revenue, while incremental operation and 
maintenance costs were charged for each year. 
 
64.  The  Project’s  financial  internal  rate  of  return  of  9.3%  compares  favorably  with  the 
estimated weighted average cost of capital of 2.54%, indicating financial viability of the Project. 
Financial viability was gauged by comparing the incremental costs and benefits of with- and 
without-project investment scenarios. The incremental benefits arise from the availability of 
power through the transmission system due to the improved substation, whereas the without-
project scenario foresees a deterioration of the assets leading to increasing operational costs 
and constraints in transmitting the generated electricity to the transmission line. Nonquantifiable 
benefits such as geological incidents were not included in the financial evaluation. Summary 
financial analysis is in Appendix 10. 
 
65.  For both the financial and economic analyses, with- and without-project scenarios have 
been  modeled  to  compare  the  overall  net  benefits  of  the  Project.  The  major  benefits  are 
identified as follows: 
 
(i)  Less outages and better reliability. The relocation and/or reconstruction of the 
switchyards does not lead to increased energy generation, and thus does not 
generate incremental increase in revenues. However, the Project secures the 
future flow of revenue to Barki Tajik. If the switchyard is not reconstructed, the 
existing switchyard will gradually break down, disrupt the energy supply from 
Nurek HEPP, and result in a loss of revenue from energy sales. Thus, the 
secured revenue from future energy generation may be attributed to the Project. 
 
(ii)  Elimination of geological avoidance and related costs. Although geological 
events are an issue with the existing switchyard (both landslide and subsidence 
of the existing switchyard site), due to the unpredictability of geological events no 
analysis has been done with regard to a hypothetical landslide and subsidence. 
However,  for  the  without-project  scenario,  subsidence  prevention  costs  have 
been included initially at $30,000 in 2009, escalating by a factor of $50,000 per 
annum due to the increased difficulties of prevention measures year after year. 
As the Project will be moved to a different location, the investment scenario does 
not include this cost as there is no subsidence. 
 
66.  Economic Benefits. The Project is least cost. It is a part of Tajikistan’s integrated 
generation  and  transmission  expansion  plan,  and  an  integrated  component  of  providing 
Tajikistan’s  major  source  of  generation  using  least-cost  planning  principles.  The  economic 
analysis  was  based  on  a  time-slice  approach  to  the  Project.  The  Project  will  stabilize 
transmission of the majority of Tajikistan’s electricity generation to the population. Cost–benefit

68.  The Project does not entail land acquisition and resettlement (LAR) and does not involve

construction of the dam body. Barki Tajik has been granted the land-use rights, and the area

73.  The Project is technically complicated given its advanced technology content and the 
need for the two new switchyards to be integrated both with each other and with the existing 
power station. However, the overall technical risk is deemed to be low based on 
 
(i)  the probability of repeat of poor ground conditions at the new site location being 
remote, as a detailed geological survey confirming the suitability of the new site 
was carried out during the feasibility study stage; 
(ii)  the  implementation  consultant  being  selected  using  a  technical-financial 
weighting of 90:10, thereby putting a high emphasis on quality; 
(iii)  the  existing  PMU,  which  has  experience  on  similar  donor-funded  projects, 
implementing the Project; 
(iv)  technically and economically viable bids, which are expected following consultant 
interaction with potential bidders during the feasibility study stage; 
(v)  bidder  qualification  criteria  that  will  ensure  that  only  competent  and  proven 
contractors are eligible to bid; 
(vi)  parallel  implementation  of  a  related  220  kV  switchyard  project,  which  is  on 
schedule  with  signing  of  loan  agreement  and  selection  of  implementation 
consultant having been completed; and 
(vii)  implementation risk of the 500 kV project being minimized, with the proposed 
selection of a turnkey contractor who will have single overall responsibility.

2.  The predominance of hydroelectric-based energy creates a problem for Tajikistan as

D.  Problems and Opportunities 
15.  The main issues faced by the Tajik energy sector are: 
 
(i)  despite  well-developed  infrastructure,  the  country  faces  energy  deficits  and 
cannot meet its winter demand; 
(ii)  the infrastructure is in poor technical condition with the problem compounded by 
a shift in electricity consumption patterns; 
(iii)  the  historically  low  level  of  electricity  pricing  impedes  necessary  resource 
mobilization; 
(iv)  the  institutional  framework  does  not  reflect  the  needs  of  a  market-oriented 
economy, and lacks commercial orientation;  
(v)  the state-owned enterprise Barki Tajik needs major restructuring; and 
(vi)  despite having abundant electricity generation potential, including some partly 
completed hydropower resources and some power-hungry electricity markets in 
neighboring countries, the country is exploiting this potential suboptimally. 
 
16.  In 2005, Tajikistan developed a strategy based on a two-track approach for the domestic 
and export markets. The first track focuses on the domestic market, and comprises a set of 
policy and investment measures aimed to bring the sector to reasonable operating conditions 
and improve its financial viability. The policy measures include (i) the implementation of a 
medium-term tariff policy; (ii) a social protection policy for energy services to improve the 
effectiveness of the scheme and ensure a more targeted approach to support the poor; and (iii) 
an institutional reform policy for the energy sector to improve the transparency and efficiency of 
operations, enable electricity trade, and pave the way for private sector participation in the 
sector. The investment measures include implementation of programs for (i) increased energy 
efficiency; (ii) demand-side management including a heat supply strategy; and (iii) increasing 
energy supply to meet winter demand, with focus on rehabilitation of existing assets. The 
second track focuses on increasing electricity exports by (i) using existing seasonal surpluses in 
the summer, and (ii) attracting private sector investors to join in developing newer hydroelectric 
and thermal capacities for exports to neighboring and regional countries.   
 
E.  Current Power Sector Developments 
17.  Winter supply deficit continues to be a problem despite imports of electricity from the 
Kyrgyz Republic, Turkmenistan, and Uzbekistan. Barki Tajik is implementing improved rationing 
procedures whereby load shedding commences earlier in the season resulting in improved 
supply during the coldest winter months. However, solution of the winter deficit problem will 
require  new  HEPPs  with  seasonal  storage  capacity  and/or  additional  thermal  generation 
capacity. Regarding possible new thermal generation, a United States Trade and Development 
Agency-funded study, due to commence in 2008, will examine the viability of commercial coal 
mine developments for which a thermal power plant would be a potential customer. 
18.  The Sangtuda1 670 MW HEPP, 70% owned by RAO UES of Russia and 30% by the 
Government, is under construction, with completion scheduled for 2009. Following the Shanghai 
Cooperation  Organization  meeting  in  Tajikistan  in  August  2009,  the  governments  of  the 
People’s Republic of China and the Russian Federation have signed agreements with the

A.  Background 
1.  The  Nurek  500  kV  Switchyard  Reconstruction  Project  to  be  funded  by  the  Asian

(EIRR) compares the annual streams of economic capital and operating costs against benefits 
based on willingness to pay. All costs, benefits, and revenues are expressed in 2009 constant 
prices. The analysis period includes the construction period and 40 years of operation. Details

Supplementary  Appendix  C.  In  the  absence  of  this  Project,  there  will  be  chronic  supply 
shortages. Demand forecasts and cost–benefit projections were prepared and analyzed, and 
they indicated that the Project is economically viable. The economic analysis confirms that the 
Project is economically viable.

4.  Without-Project  Scenario. The economic analysis assumes that, in regards to the 
without-project scenario, Barki Tajik does not have funds to rehabilitate the whole 500 kilovolt

with costs increasing by $50,000 per annum. A catastrophic scenario with regard to a landslide 
or subsidence has been ignored for purposes of the economic analysis. 
 
5.  Annual output of the Nurek HEPP via the 500 kV switchyard is assumed to decrease by 
60% during the 10 years of rehabilitation. Once rehabilitation is complete, the switchyard is 
assumed to transmit 90% of the total energy of 7,500 gigawatt-hours (GWh) due to shutdowns 
because of subsidence prevention measures and minor landslides. 
 
D.  Quantification of Benefits 
6.  The benefits of avoided equipment breakdown and avoided geological catastrophes can 
be quantified in terms of avoided loss of energy, measured in kWh. Additionally, the avoided 
costs of risk mitigation and of repairs after equipment failures, measured in US dollars, have to 
be considered. In the following, the avoided loss of energy and the avoided mitigation costs are 
quantified separately for the geological risk and for the breakdown of aging equipment. The 
impact of loss of energy on the other economies in Central Asia cannot be quantified and is 
therefore not further considered in the following quantitative analysis. 
 
1.  Effect of Equipment Breakdown 
7.  The switchyard is over 35 years old and worn out. As explained in para. 5, the without-
project scenario foresees failures of individual components and increased shutdowns forcing 
Barki Tajik to rehabilitate using its own funds. During 10 years of rehabilitation, the model 
assumes 60% of the generated electricity to be transmitted though the 500 kV switchyard, and 
90% thereafter. 
 
2.  Effect of Geological Risk 
8.  The subsidence in the 500 kV switchyard destabilizes the equipment. In order to avoid 
the collapse of towers, Barki Tajik monitors the areas for sinkholes, fills them, adds extensions 
to the legs of the towers and strengthens the foundations with concrete. In the without-project 
case, this procedure needs to be continued at an annual cost of approximately $30,000. So far, 
this procedure has successfully prevented equipment failure and no energy was lost due to 
uplifting and/or subsidence. It is assumed that in the future the mitigation measures will continue 
to  be  successful.  The  annual  cost  is  increased  by  $50,000  per  annum  due  to  increased 
difficulties of uplifting and/or subsidence as time goes by. 
 
E.  Valuation of Benefits 
9.  The avoided cost of risk mitigation and damage repair is expressed in monetary terms 
as explained above, but the monetary value of the lost energy also needs to be determined for 
the economic analysis. There are several options for this valuation:

1.  Cost of Unserved Energy 
10.  The economic costs of unserved energy have been estimated in numerous studies. In 
the literature on economic costs of outages, costs are generally broken down into short- and 
long-run costs. Short-run costs comprise product spoilage and damage to machinery, shutdown 
and restart costs, forgone revenues from underutilized production capacities. Long-run costs are 
mainly identified with the cost of mitigating the effects of power outages with standby generators 
or by switching completely to self-generation. Estimates for the cost of unserved energy depend 
on the country and the consumer category; they range between $0.10 per kilowatt-hour (kWh) 
and $0.50 per kWh for households, and over $1/kWh for commercial and industrial consumers. 
 
2.  Willingness to Pay 
11.  The willingness of consumers to pay for electricity is usually derived from the amount 
spent on other sources of energy when electricity is not available, such as candles, kerosene, 
and stand-by generators. This amount depends on the uses of electricity and is different for 
particular groups and consumers. In the evaluation of ADB projects in the past,1 the willingness 
to pay was estimated at $0.20/kWh based on the cost of auto-generation at a 10% utilization 
factor. The Power Sector Development Project2 valued the unserved energy at twice the long-
run marginal cost, or at $0.042/kWh, which was also equivalent to the average import tariff. 
 
3.  Value of Energy Import 
12.  It is unlikely that the Government of Tajikistan will not look for other sources of supply 
when the supply from Nurek HEPP is interrupted. The contribution of the Tajik Aluminum 
Company (TALCO, a major aluminum joint stock company in Tajikistan and by far the largest 
customer of Barki Tajik) to the gross domestic product of Tajikistan is considered so important 
that in the winter, when domestic energy supply is insufficient, energy for TALCO is imported 
from Uzbekistan at an import tariff much higher than the tariff paid by TALCO. It is therefore 
methodologically not justified to value the lost energy in the without-project situation at the cost 
of unserved energy (damage cost and mitigation cost) or at the willingness to pay. 
 
13.  It  is  more  appropriate  to  use  the  value  of  alternative  sources  of  electricity  supply, 
including import from Uzbekistan (currently at $0.015/kWh with a capacity of 1,200 MW) and 
generation from Sangtuda I and Rogun HEPPs. Sangtuda is expected to be operational in 2010, 
while Rogun is planned to be commissioned later. Both plants are built to serve the export 
market, but in an emergency situation the energy could be diverted for domestic use. The value 
of this energy is then equal to the forgone export tariff, estimated at $0.02–$0.03/kWh. For the 
purpose of the economic analysis, an average value of $0.02/kWh is used.

A.  Introduction 
 
1.  Financial management of Barki Tajik was reviewed and found to be adequate. Barki 
Tajik  has  the  ability  to  undertake  and  fulfill  fiduciary  requirements  for  the  Nurek  500  kV 
Switchyard Reconstruction Project. Financial management assessment questionnaires and field 
interviews  were  used  to  review  the  present  standing  of  financial  management.  Due 
consideration has been given to the fact that Barki Tajik is in transition from being a vertically 
integrated  government  company  to  a  fully  independent  corporate  entity.  Progress  on 
strengthening corporate governance and financial management is under way. 
 
1.  Corporate Structure 
2.  Barki  Tajik  is  the  state-owned  utility  responsible  for  generation,  transmission,  and 
distribution of electricity in Tajikistan. Prior to the country’s independence, Barki Tajik was 
administratively a Government entity. A detailed corporate structure and an analysis of Barki 
Tajik’s financial management is in Supplementary Appendix D. 
 
3.  In 1992, Barki Tajik became a state joint stock holding company. Although it is fully 
owned by the Government, Barki Tajik enjoys autonomous status according to its charter. In 
2000, Barki Tajik was incorporated as a commercial entity and a formal separation of operations 
took place along its business lines. In 2004, Barki Tajik was merged with the Ministry of Energy 
and Industry. In March 2006, this merger was revoked and Barki Tajik separated from the 
Ministry of Energy and Industry. 
 
4.  Barki  Tajik  is  managed  by  a  chair  and  a  board  of  directors  appointed  by  the 
Government. Ten general services departments (among them planning, accounting, and sales) 
report directly to the Barki Tajik chair, who also manages issues of great importance, such as 
the  power  supply  contract  with  Tajik  Aluminum  Company  (TALCO,  the  largest  industrial 
consumer with 40% of total consumption), or the financing of new investment projects. The 
overall staff of the utility is about 11,480 people, of whom about 290 work in the head office in 
Dushanbe. 
 
B.  Financial Management Issues and Mitigating Measures 
 
5.  The financial sustainability of the power transmission sector is dependent on timely and 
accurate  (i)  submission  of  tariff  applications  by  Barki  Tajik,  (ii)  execution  of  the  tariff 
determination by the Ministry of Economic Development and Trade, (iii) notification of the tariff 
determination  by  the  Government,  and  (iv)  collection  of  payments  from  customers.  As  for 
corporate issues, Barki Tajik has financial and management independence issues that need to 
be remedied. 
 
1.  Tariff Issues 
 
6.  In the tariff determination, the revenue requirement to cover general establishment and 
administrative expenses, repair and maintenance, depreciation, and costs are determined by 
Barki Tajik’s planning department and are submitted to the Ministry of Economic Development 
and Trade. 
 
7.  Tariffs are supposed to be regulated by the Anti Monopoly Commission, which played a

regulatory role until 2006. After the election in 2007, the Cabinet of Ministers was reorganized 
and  the  regulatory  body  was  integrated  as  a  department  within  the  Ministry  of  Economic 
Development and Trade. However, neither before the reorganization nor after did the regulator 
exercise its function of independent tariff setting. Due to the high political and social sensitivity 
of electricity tariffs in transition countries, it is typical that the governments are the ultimate 
institution in the approval process. On a semiannual basis Barki Tajik proposes tariff increases, 
trying to reach cost-recovery level, but in the past these have either not been approved or only 
partially accepted by the Government. 
 
8.  The current process is relatively new and before tariff increases for 2008 were approved, 
tariffs had not been raised for the last 5 years. Currently, after submission by Barki Tajik, the 
application for the new tariff is reviewed by the Ministry of Economic Development and Trade 
and is sent to the Government and is ultimately approved by the President. 
 
9.  Due to pressures from the international financial institutions (IFIs), tariffs were calculated 
up to 2010 and approved by the President in January 2008. It is not known if this system will 
work for tariffs after 2010; however, the IFIs take comfort from the fact that the Government is 
serious in its efforts in restructuring and eventual unbundling and privatizing of Barki Tajik. 
 
2.  Financial Independence 
 
10.  Barki Tajik has direct access to foreign exchange for the purchase of spare parts and 
other equipment, but the company is unable to finance new investment and the necessary 
rehabilitation of its aging power system from its own cash flow. The gap is only partially filled by 
subsidies  from  the  Government.  Funds  from  foreign  donors  are  given  to  the  Government 
through the Ministry of Finance who onlends them to Barki Tajik. Even in the cases when the 
bilateral aid takes the forms of grants, the funds are onlent with an interest rate to the utility, in 
order to give Barki Tajik ownership of and responsibility for the funds. 
 
11.  Barki Tajik currently has satisfactory accounting capacities and established accredited 
external audit processes in accordance with international audit standards. In addition, Barki 
Tajik has developed sufficient in-house functions and systems to handle payments, billings, and 
collections. 
 
12.  The plans and budgets of Barki Tajik and its business units are (i) reconciled and 
approved as integrated documents, (ii) partially commercially independent of the Government, 
and (iii) developed to meet commercial needs. However, forward projections are checked by the 
Government to ensure compliance with approved national socioeconomic policies. Due to the 
general lack of funds, operating objectives often have to be revised downwards to a level that 
can be realistically achieved. The constant shortage of cash renders any planning difficult. 
Elaborate planning systems comprising target parameters, monitoring systems, and sanctions 
for deviations from the targets are not workable in such a system of scarcity, which instead calls 
for a high level of flexibility. Management cannot be held accountable for deficiencies resulting 
from lack of funds. However, there are appropriate sanctions for staff who fail to reach targets 
for other reasons, e.g., billing and collection in the energy sales companies. 
 
3.  Management Independence 
 
13.  As the transition period is in process and Barki Tajik has built capacity for independence 
from the Government, the corporate governance structure of its board should be in accordance 
with international best practices. The Asian Development Bank (ADB) is currently supporting

directors.

SUMMARY OF FINANCIAL ANALYSIS  
 
A.  Introduction 
1.  The financial analysis of the Project has been carried out in accordance with the Asian 
Development Bank’s Financial Management and Analysis of Projects.1 All financial costs and 
benefits were expressed in 2009 prices. Cost streams used for the purposes of financial internal 
rate of return (FIRR) determination—i.e., capital investment, operation and maintenance, insurance 
costs, and taxes—reflect the costs of delivering the estimated benefits. 
 
B.  Assumptions  
2.  Capital  costs  were  estimated  in  US  dollars  expressed  in  constant  prices  over  the 
construction period of 3 years for the new switchyard. Capital costs were derived from local 
sources,  which  include  physical  contingencies  at  5%  of  base  costs.  Price  contingencies  and 
interest during construction were excluded from the estimation of capital costs for the purpose of 
the FIRR, which is in 2009 prices.  
 
3.  Financial viability was examined by comparing the incremental costs and benefits of with- 
and without-project investment scenarios. The relocation and reconstruction of the switchyards 
does not lead to increased energy generation, and thus does not generate incremental increase in 
revenues. However, the Project secures the future flow of revenues to Barki Tajik. If the switchyard 
is not reconstructed, the existing switchyard will gradually break down, disrupt the energy supply 
from the Nurek Hydroelectric Power Plant (HEPP), and result in a loss of revenue from energy 
sales. Thus, the secured revenue from future energy generation may be attributed to the Project. 
 
4.  The without-project investment scenario comprises the existing facility of the switchyard 
deteriorating in 5 years and Barki Tajik replacing it with a new air-insulated switchgear system over 
10 years due to a lack of funds preventing it from being rehabilitated all at once. 
 
5.  Due to the unpredictability of geological events, no analysis has been undertaken with 
regard to landslide and subsidence. However, subsidence prevention costs were included initially 
at $30,000 in 2009, escalating by a factor of $50,000 per annum due to the increased difficulties of 
prevention measures year after year. As the Project will be moved to a different location, the 
investment scenario does not include this cost as there is no subsidence. 
 
C.  Tariff Methodology 
6.  The revenue of Nurek HEPP is derived from the share of generation in the cost-covering 
tariff that has been adjusted for losses. Barki Tajik plans to increase the average end-user tariff to 
the long-run marginal cost level ($0.025/kWh) by 2010. This tariff needs to cover the entire cost of 
energy supply, including generation, transmission, and distribution. The share of generation in the 
long-run marginal cost, and thus in the end-user tariff, is approximately 22% (i.e., $0.0055/kWh).2  
 
7.  Considering that the end-user tariff refers to energy sold, not energy generated, this value 
has  to  be  further  adjusted.  The  difference  between  energy  generated  and  energy  sold  is 
represented by the system and commercial losses. Target system and commercial losses are 10% 
in 2012, but, using a conservative approach, 15% is assumed for this analysis.

9.  For estimating the weighted average cost of capital (WACC), it is assumed that the Asian

11.  The sensitivity analysis serves to test the effect of changes in key parameters on the

4.  Reporting Requirements 
 
7.  Pre-Construction Phase. The consultant will prepare an inception report after 1 month 
from mobilization, and a draft final report including the conceptual design and bid documents. 
The consultants will also prepare bid evaluation reports for each contract. 
 
8.  Construction  Phase.  The  consultant  will  prepare  monthly  progress  reports  to  be 
submitted within 2 weeks from the end of the month that is being reported. Quarterly progress 
reports will be prepared and submitted within 1 month from the end of the quarter that is being 
reported. The format of the progress reports shall be drafted by the consultant and endorsed by 
the EA and ADB, and they should include, but not be limited to, physical progress against the 
schedule and a plan for the next term, disbursement against the schedule and a plan for the 
next term, quality test results, safety control, survey of quantity when required, environmental 
monitoring, social issues including land acquisition and resettlement, and any other issues to be 
raised. Annual reports will be prepared by the consultants and shall be submitted within 1 month 
from the end of the year that is being reported. Variation orders and any other documents 
deemed necessary by the EA and/or ADB will be prepared. A project completion report will be 
prepared within 1 month after completion.
